messages: 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:06): grr ... why is offline GMail a Chrome app and not a Web app? https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/ejidjjhkpiempkbhmpbfngldlkglhimk
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:11): More general: why doesn't the Chrome Web Store support other browsers?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:11): "Sorry, we don't support your browser just yet. You'll need Google Chrome to install apps, extensions and themes."
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:11): That makes it sound like they intend to add support eventually, but . . .

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:14): I imagine they will add support for other browsers eventually, since to do otherwise seems inconsistent with their general approach to the web.  But it's pretty annoying that they seem not to view that as urgent.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:14): has no more idea than anyone what the Chrome Web Store or Gmail people are thinking, obviously
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:15): who knows, but there must certainly be a huge temptation to follow Apple and Microsoft into proprietary app stores
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:16): Why?  Google makes virtually all its money off ads, and Firefox displays ads as well as Chrome does.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:17): What money it does make directly off the store will only be increased if it allows more browsers to use it.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:18): Unlike Microsoft and Apple, Google doesn't have a history of trying to obtain lock-in, and in fact has often tended to do the opposite -- make switching to other services as easy as possible.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:18): E.g., Gmail supports unlimited forwarding, IMAP, etc. out of the box, which (AFAIK) some other major webmail providers don't.
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:19): yeah, they've been good
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:19): but if they get lots of good stuff into the Chrome app store, then that increases Chrome usage
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:20): and that translates into power over the Web, and app developers
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:20): google's mobile browser support has been terrible for web apps, in my experience
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:20): seems like they really don't care
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:21): we'll see how things go down
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:21): just trying to implement a basic full-screen web app in android's browser (at least as of 2.3.x) is a nightmare

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:22): but I really want offline GMail and I don't want to have to switch to Chrome to get it (nor do I want other people to have to switch to Chrome to get it, of course)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:22): "installed web apps" should be considered an oxymoron
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:23): all of the "chrome apps" and all that nonsense just kills what's great about web apps
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:30): offline GMail uses WebSQL, which is dead as a standard
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:30): (because using a language that every programmer in the world already intuitively understands is overrated; we Need More Wheels)
bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc (01:33): the new offline gmail uses websql? i thought it just used filesystem (although i'm not directly involved)

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:33): in fact, the "SQL" every programmer in the world intuitively understands is different things to different people and often quite different to the SQLite 3.6.19 or whatever that WebSQL is
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:33): bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc: khuey looked at it and that's what he says
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:33): but regardless of the detabable merits of WebSQL, its deadness as a standard is a fact
bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc (01:34): good thing offline gmail isn't part of the web, then
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:35): two wrongs don't make a right

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:35): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: it doesn't matter if it's different in the details, the basic language (and most of the day-to-day as well) is well-understood, which makes learning variants easy

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:35): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427, there's not any realistic alternative, though, given the low adoption so far of IDB.  Not to mention the fact that it's staggeringly complicated to use for even the most trivial use-cases.
bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc (01:35): i have no idea what lead to that decision
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:35): One line of localStorage that's instantly understandable to any web developer is so many lines of IDB that I've given up every time I tried it.
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:36): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: it is supported in Chrome though, so if you're going to write a Chrome app ...
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:36): Well, true.

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:36): (similar to a major reason svn was so successful: it was very intuitive to cvs users, so you only had to learn the differences, where eg. git being so different gives it a much higher learning curve)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:36): But I suspect it's a lot harder to learn and use, especially given that anyone writing this sort of app already knows some sort of SQL.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:37): At least, I'm pretty sure I could pick up WebSQL a heck of a lot more easily.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:37): I wouldn't be surprised if WebSQL has way more features and better performance at this point, too.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:38): Not that I'm saying people should use WebSQL instead of IDB, but there are pretty clear reasons for doing so.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:42): Does anyone know if there's a Mozilla bug for supporting Node.contains()?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:42): If not, I'll file one.
